children.subject:
thanks a lot! I am not quite sure about quant trader or swe.

I did not include eecs 126/127 because I heard that there is a lot overlapping between those two classes and ind eng 160/162; is it right?
I don't know much about the ieor classes either, but I have heard that 126/127 are more rigorous (someone correct me if I'm wrong).

If you want to do research in ML/AI, you should try to take 189 ASAP. You should also take 127/126 as well, a lot of the math taught in those two classes are relevant to ML research. For quant, it depends if you are interested in being a trader or being a SWE. Being a trader requires you to have very sharp probability/statistics skills, so you should take a look at 126 and also some stats upper divs (idk much about the stats classes). To be a swe at a quant, you should be well-versed in systems/low-level knowledge, so classes like 162, 161, 186 (the latter 2 less so) are very important.
thanks a lot for the advice. what other stat/math classes would you recommend except eecs 126/127?
Look into Math 113, Math 110, Math 53, Cs 182, Cs 188, or Math 104. Don’t know too much about stats though.
I'd recommend Stat 150 and Stat 153 (though 150 has a lot of overlap with EECS 126)
thanks everyone! so just to clarify, if I take eecs 126 instead of stat 134, am I good to take classes (stat 150, stat 135) with stat 134 prerequisite?
thanks! also, for the stat minor, am I allowed to replace stat 134 with eecs 126?

Probably want to replace the ieor classes with eecs 126 and 127, another note if you take my advice 126 is a superset of stat 134 so u can replace that class with something else. Want to take 170, 126, and 127 before taking 189
so you can focus on the ML concepts instead of the math

<md>If you're interested in ML research, then take:
126, 127, and 189. Ideally you'd want to take one of 126 or 127 before 189. I have found that 127 is more useful

If you're interested in quant research/trading, then take:
126 and maybe some stats classes like 135. I cannot comment on the usefulness of stats classes however as I have not taken them myself

If you're interested in quant SWE, then take:
162

I can speak from experience for the first and last ones but I have not gotten a quant research/trader internship so I cannot comment on the best strategy for that. I have done interviews for quant trader/research and most of them are doable given just what you learn in 126, some of them are doable even with CS 70 knowledge. Most of those industrial engineering classes don't seem useful for what you're trying to do. I agree with Helix's comment to take 189 asap. 169 doesn't seem too useful given the general area of interest, most recommend just doing internships and I would agree with that sentiment.

After taking CS 70 and EECS 16b, it is most logical to take one or both of 126 and 127. Needless to say, these are super useful classes for what you're interested in, and I also enjoyed them a lot. I am assuming you are currently a freshman, in which case I will say that it could be difficult to find quant research/trader internships for your sophomore-junior year summer given that you will not have covered much probability by the time recruiting season starts. If you care about finding a quant trader internship then I recommend going through some books on probability and perhaps even some books specific to quant interviews.

I also saw another comment to take math 113 and math 110. You do not need to take either of these. I have taken math 113 formally and have self studied the material for math 110 (using the Axler book). Math 113 is almost completely useless for what you're interested in and math 110 might be too theoretical to the point where 127 is enough. Math 104 is useful for the research side of ML. If possible, I'd recommend trying to replace stat 134 with 126 if possible since the latter covers a lot more new concepts compared to CS 70 probability</md>

history.content:
I am an intended cs student and I need advice for course selection. I am interested in machine learning/quant dev/research. I am also quite interested in its applications in finance; however I think it is better to take quantitative (stat, cs, math) classes during my undergrad years - what do you think about this? And then go to a grad school in fintech/financial engineering/quant.

I have made a rough study sample (cs major + ieor minor); what suggestions do you have to add or replace the following courses which are suitable for ML/quant?

I have already taken:

Summer 2020: breadth 1

Fall 2020: math 1b + data 8 + r&c1

Spring 2021: cs 61a + eecs 16a + math 53 + r&c2

I plan to take:

Summer 2021: cs 61bl

Fall 2021: cs 70 + eecs 16b + stat 134 + breadth 2 

Spring 2022: cs 61c (breadth 3) + data c100 + stat 135 + breadth 4

Fall 2022: cs 162 + cs 186 + ind eng 162 + breadth 5

Spring 2023: cs 169 + cs 170 + ind eng 173 + breadth 6

Fall 2023: cs 188 + ind eng 115 + breadth 7 + spare (add smth)

Spring 2024: cs 189 + ind eng 171 + 2 spare (add smth)

thank you in advance
history.subject: Need avice!
